items.title: With New Glenn Rocket a Success, Blue Origin's Next Step Is to Build a $100 Billion Orbital Reef
items.author: The Motley Fool
items.description: Blue Origin, founded by Jeff Bezos, plans to build a $100 billion Orbital Reef space station to replace the International Space Station. The station will include advanced research facilities and luxurious living quarters, targeting high-end space tourism.

insights.sentiment_reasoning: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Blue Origin, is a major shareholder of Amazon.com, which could potentially help fund the Orbital Reef project.
Boeing is also a partner of Blue Origin in the Orbital Reef project, indicating a joint effort to develop the space station.
Boeing is also a partner of Blue Origin in the Orbital Reef project, indicating a joint effort to develop the space station.
Redwire is another partner of Blue Origin in the Orbital Reef project, contributing to the development of the space station.
Redwire is another partner of Blue Origin in the Orbital Reef project, contributing to the development of the space station.
Northrop Grumman is part of the team building the Starlab space station, which is a competing project to the Orbital Reef.
Hilton Hotels is also part of the team building the Starlab space station, indicating its involvement in the space tourism industry.
Airbus is a partner of Voyager Technologies in the Starlab space station project, contributing to the development of a competing space station.
Virgin Galactic is a competitor to Blue Origin in the space tourism industry, but it has been grounded since retiring its Unity spaceplane in June 2024.
